	<item>
		<title>America - The land of secondary inspections</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 18 Jun 2011 05:02:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>varun.krishna</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=14</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In Vancouver for a wedding and had a chance to catch up with some friends - a couple of whom have started a company here in good old Canada.  They were forced to move up here from the bay area where things were going quite well and had to relocate due to visa complications. It's amazing to me how hard it is to start a company in the US if you are not a green card holder or an American citizen.  

As a holder of a pending green card application (with 3-5 years to go to boot) - every single damn time I enter the US I'm forced by law to go through a secondary inspection that requires 2-3 hours of advance airport arrival, being treated like you have no right to be where you are, and could very well result in a missed flight. 

Why are you making things harder for yourself America? Not everyone is a border jumper.  Some of us actually add economic value.  Can you afford to let the next facebook/google/microsoft occur outside just because it was inspired by dare I say it....a "Canadian"? eh? 

Kind of reminds me of the Simpson's episode where Homer is stuck in a well trying to dig his way out.  "You're doing it wrong. Dig up stupid!"

-v]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date>2011-06-18 05:02:02</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>america-the-land-of-secondary-inspections</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Alan Greenspan, you&#8217;re alright by me.</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 18 Jun 2011 18:33:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=19</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>&#160;</p>  <p>It needs to be said, so I will say it: I like Alan Greenspan. He’s both a funny old man, and an avid bit coin miner (or so I presume)</p>  <p><img src="http://www.princeton.edu/~pkrugman/greenspan.jpg" /></p>  <p>Before I go any further. Just look at him! Is that the face of Wall Street greed and excess?</p>  <p>It’s become en vogue to hate on Greenspan because of that little thing we like to refer to as “the housing bubble”. The buck and the blame for which always seems to land on Greenspan’s lap.</p>  <p>Yes, interest rates were too low. But come on now, imagine you are Greenspan and its 2002. The dot-com bubble had just Hezbollah-ed in our faces, Al Qeda had attacked Tribeca, what’s a Federal Reserve governor to do? Lower rates!</p>  <p>And while many of you say its not his lowering of the rates in 2001-2002 that were to blame, but rather his maintenance of these low rates up until 2005. </p>  <p>These Greenspan haters will say that the housing bubble was all part of Greenspan’s Joker-esque plan. He wanted housing prices to grow ridiculously out of line just so he could line his pockets with all the Big Derivative money he’d get in the process.</p>  <p>It’s almost as if Greenspan saw the future housing bubble, and the trillion dollar calamity that came after it, and said ‘you know what, fuck it, im still gonna plunge the world into the next great depression so I can line my pockets for the 7 years of life I have left’.</p>  <p>In the words of the short little chef in Ratatouille, “I find that highly suspect!”</p>  <p>Did Greenspan keep rates too low? Perhaps. Did they lead to the housing bubble? Perhaps. Does that make him a monster? No!</p>  <p> You know what, if I were the chairman of the Federal Reserve, there aint no way in hell I am raising interest rates in 2003, 2004, or 2005. You know why? </p>  <p>Because I’m not a dick. </p>  <p>Every basis point increase in the fed prime rate manifests itself on the streets of the US in the form of layoffs, closings, and foreclosures. Raising rates in 2004 would have put in jeopardy an economic recovery which had not happened outside of the housing market. It’s not like we were all burning $10 bills in the good ole days of ‘04 and ‘05. Lets be real, we haven’t had a good economic party since the Cisco IPO.</p>  <p>Greenspan is not a dick. </p>  <p>He’s just an old man, who upon going into retirement gave us a few more drops out of the money spigot. Like an extended last call called by a bartender, or the bumper car operator at Six Flags who lets the ride go for 2 minutes longer than it should.&#160; He let the rates stay low for no other reason that it helped us as a country get better economically. Even if that meant an asset bubble formed in areas of the economy.</p>  <p>No, he is not evil. He is not to blame. He’s just a guy, perched upon one of the loneliest seats in the world, who decided that he was done playing God to millions of people.</p>  <p>However, I will have to admit. He does bear an uncanny resemblance to a monkey:</p>  <p><img src="http://images.cheezburger.com/completestore/2010/2/17/129109436707060018.jpg" /></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>19</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-06-18 18:33:05</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-06-18 18:33:05</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>alan-greenspan-youre-alright-by-me</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Arguing with Reality</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Jun 2011 20:55:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>varun.krishna</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=20</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I don't know much, but I do know that if you argue with reality - you will lose 100% of the time.  It's the only thing that is guaranteed.  Reality is absolute, it is things that have happened and it is moment to moment. Time can only move forward so why do people reflect on the past - why do they wish they could relive moments, why do they spend countless hours toiling in the depths of negative thinking be it self-caused, or indirectly assumed?

Because it's easy.

It's easy to focus on negative things because it plays on our innate fears.  As human beings we are fear-driven creatures.  Fear necessitates everything we do - and every emotion we experience, whether it be our love, our faith, our passion, our need for apprecaition, and our anger - all it takes is a little investigation to figure out that it is born of a fear that we posess within ourselves.

So what would be  like if we weren't afraid of anything? Even our own mortality?

Maybe it would mean we would never argue with reality.  And not arguing with reality, means not being upset, angry or stressed out by any moment life chucks at us.  In the words of the great Jed McKenna - the universe is just a big playful puppy.  Sometimes it gets excited and plays a little rough, but it's still your puppy.

Recognize it for that which it is.  That's the key to happiness, contentment and any other thing you want.

PS. He really does look like a monkey.  How do we still not believe in evolution?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Why&#8217;s the Post Office so big?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2011 05:36:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=22</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Real estate in Manhattan is not cheap. In fact, I might be as bold to suggest that Manhattan real estate is rather pricy. My apartment, which is a 500 sq ft studio in Hell's Kitchen, costs $2300 a month to rent. Ok, so its not cheap.</p>  <p>Take this thought, put it in your satchel, and come for a walk with me along 9th and 10th avenues in Manhattan. Amidst the rabble of homeless people, and cavalcades of wide-eyed tourists, you might have spotted this:</p>  <p><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1887.jpg"><img style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; border-left: 0px; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; display: inline; border-top: 0px; border-right: 0px; padding-top: 0px" title="IMG_1887" border="0" alt="IMG_1887" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1887_thumb.jpg" width="541" height="407" /></a></p>  <p>No, its not a sports-stadium. Its not an airport. Its the size of a city block, so what could it be?</p>  <p>A post office.</p>  <p>But wait, just across the street from Nero's Postal Palace, we find:</p>  <p><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1888.jpg"><img style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; border-left: 0px; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; display: inline; border-top: 0px; border-right: 0px; padding-top: 0px" title="IMG_1888" border="0" alt="IMG_1888" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1888_thumb.jpg" width="435" height="578" /></a></p>  <p>Another postal building! </p>  <p>And these aren't small Duane Reader sized outlets, each of these buildings covers an entire Manhattan block. Not to mention another huge facility which sits at 12th Avenue and 26th Street.</p>  <p>Ok, I am going to put some of those McKinsey skills to work here and back of the envelope how much money the Federal Government could receive in commercial leases if they &quot;moved&quot; these buildings elsewhere:</p>  <p>Google Earth tells me that these buildings in total cover 1,000,000 square feet of land. If you could build a 20-story tower on this land, that would introduce 20,000,000 sq. feet of office space. </p>  <p>If we assume that being in Midtown West, one could conceivably convert this into commercial Class A real-estate, which might be worth $50 per sq ft per month.</p>  <p>Thats <b>$12 billion per year</b> in potential lease revenue! </p>  <p><b>You could buy some B-2 bombers with that shit kid.</b></p>  <p>Hold on a second, that’s a lot of money, and this is only the United States Postal Service.</p>  <p>Let's not kid ourselves , shipping and sorting post cards is not quite the same thing as assembling a Saturn V rocket. (which I'm sure could be done inside this building at 28th:</p>  <p><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1891.jpg"><img style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; border-left: 0px; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; display: inline; border-top: 0px; border-right: 0px; padding-top: 0px" title="IMG_1891" border="0" alt="IMG_1891" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1891_thumb.jpg" width="472" height="628" /></a></p>  <p>Now, I might be playing armchair-Postmaster General, but I think its odd that we have an army of people (~600,000), with an empire of real estate that does nothing more than fill our boxes with Victoria Secret catalogues and Capital One credit cards.</p>  <p>The last time I got something in the mail that actually meant something, its return address was from the North Pole. How about you?</p>  <p><b>What else is the USPS sitting on?</b></p>  <p>I just opened up the USPS balance sheet from last year: (<a href="http://www.usps.com/financials/_pdf/usps2010annual-report.pdf">http://www.usps.com/financials/_pdf/usps2010annual-report.pdf</a>)&#160; <font size="1">(over/under on the total number of times that link has ever been clicked? i'd say 3 tops) </font></p>  <p><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/Image.jpg"><img style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; border-left: 0px; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; display: inline; border-top: 0px; border-right: 0px; padding-top: 0px" title="Image" border="0" alt="Image" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/Image_thumb.jpg" width="527" height="117" /></a></p>  <p>Yup, the USPS is sitting on&#160; $<b>20 billion of buildings,equipment and land</b>. </p>  <p>Naturally, since it is a government organization, the USPS never fails to disappoint when it comes to destroying value. In 2010, the USPS translated these assets into a Excite@Home-esque <b>$3 billion loss</b>.</p>  <p><b>With only 5 weeks till the Federal Government defaults:</b></p>  <p>Here we have the USPS sitting on at least $20 billion in assets. The weirdest part about this whole thing is that its the USPS! It ain’t exactly Social Security.&#160; I'm sure the only other budgetary line item that a constituent would ax before the USPS would contain the initials IRS.</p>  <p><b>So what's my point?</b></p>  <p>The government should shut down the USPS, liquidate its entire asset base, and used it to pay down our deficits. True, we would probably still be heading towards financial collapse, but on the bright side, at least Capital One won't be bothering us then.</p>  <p>&#160;</p>  <p><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1889.jpg"><img style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; border-left: 0px; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; display: inline; border-top: 0px; border-right: 0px; padding-top: 0px" title="IMG_1889" border="0" alt="IMG_1889" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/Whys-the-Post-Office-so-big_153E/IMG_1889_thumb.jpg" width="244" height="244" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<title>World War II: What is the smallest thing, or things, that you would have to change in history to prevent the Second World War from having happened?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 02 Jul 2011 16:31:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=27</guid>
		<description></description>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>27</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-07-02 16:31:01</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>world-war-ii-what-is-the-smallest-thing-or-things-that-you-would-have-to-change-in-history-to-prevent-the-second-world-war-from-having-happened</wp:post_name>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Why did the U.S. go to the moon?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 03 Jul 2011 13:49:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=28</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Why did the U.S. go to the moon? 6 answers on Quora<br /><br /><span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://www.quora.com/Why-did-the-U-S-go-to-the-moon">Why did the U.S. go to the moon?</a></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>28</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-07-03 13:49:06</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-07-03 13:49:06</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>why-did-the-u-s-go-to-the-moon</wp:post_name>

				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";s:15:"1309740386.4994";s:7:"message";s:28:"Akismet cleared this comment";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:0:"";}]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_as_submitted</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:116:{s:15:"comment_post_ID";s:2:"28";s:14:"comment_author";s:4:"John";s:20:"comment_author_email";s:23:"john.hinnegan@gmail.com";s:18:"comment_author_url";s:0:"";s:15:"comment_content";s:82:"did you know that it is incorrect to use both i.e. and etc. in a list of examples?";s:12:"comment_type";s:0:"";s:14:"comment_parent";s:1:"0";s:7:"user_ID";s:1:"0";s:7:"user_ip";s:13:"72.37.183.209";s:10:"user_agent";s:79:"Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0";s:8:"referrer";s:111:"http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=28&utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=why-did-the-u-s-go-to-the-moon";s:4:"blog";s:31:"http://www.oscial.com/wordpress";s:9:"blog_lang";s:5:"en_US";s:12:"blog_charset";s:5:"UTF-8";s:9:"permalink";s:37:"http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=28";s:9:"user_role";s:0:"";s:21:"akismet_comment_nonce";s:6:"passed";s:11:"POST_author";s:4:"John";s:10:"POST_email";s:23:"john.hinnegan@gmail.com";s:8:"POST_url";s:0:"";s:12:"POST_comment";s:82:"did Files";s:12:"PSModulePath";s:45:"C:Windowssystem32WindowsPowerShellv1.0Modules";s:6:"PUBLIC";s:13:"C:UsersPublic";s:11:"SystemDrive";s:2:"C:";s:10:"SystemRoot";s:9:"C:Windows";s:4:"TEMP";s:13:"C:WindowsTEMP";s:3:"TMP";s:13:"C:WindowsTEMP";s:10:"USERDOMAIN";s:7:"WINHOST";s:8:"USERNAME";s:4:"W06$";s:11:"USERPROFILE";s:36:"C:Windowssystem32configsystemprofile";s:6:"windir";s:9:"C:Windows";s:9:"FCGI_ROLE";s:9:"RESPONDER";s:15:"HTTP_CONNECTION";s:10:"keep-alive";s:19:"HTTP_CONTENT_LENGTH";s:3:"224";s:17:"HTTP_CONTENT_TYPE";s:33:"application/x-www-form-urlencoded";s:11:"HTTP_ACCEPT";s:63:"text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8";s:19:"HTTP_ACCEPT_CHARSET";s:30:"ISO-8859-1,utf-8;q=0.7,*;q=0.7";s:20:"HTTP_ACCEPT_ENCODING";s:13:"gzip, 			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The beauty of the business school application process</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Jul 2011 13:47:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=31</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Business school applications suck. The essays I had to write are by-far the single worst use of my time in adulthood, and the most painful. Yet only now have I come to realize the sublime beauty of the whole application process. Much like the sycophantic carnival that is investment banking recruiting, applying to business school is about self-selection. Make it painful enough so that the people who succeed are those who have the innate bull-shitting talent that makes a successful manager/marketer/executive/entrepreneur.

<strong><em>“You need to arch your back while keeping it flat at the same time”</em></strong>

The essays are simply absurd. On one hand you are told to be "different", and distinguish yourself from the crowd, but really, the admissions officers suffer no creativity and are looking for the same basic things in each application. So in reality, you need to be different while being exactly the same as everyone else.

Save yourself the money, don’t buy this:

<img style="margin: 0px 5px;" src="http://www.mavenpublishing.com/graphics/bookcovers/Secrets_to_Getting_into_Business_School_145x193.jpg" alt="" />

When all you really need is:

<img style="margin: 0px 5px;" src="http://school.discoveryeducation.com/clipart/images/cookbook.gif" alt="" />

<strong>Cooking the books</strong>

I have no qualms in saying that I took whatever ingredients of truth I had to work with in my background and added all the literary seasoning I could get my hands on.

I spit-shined my cookie-cutter background into a Dan Brown-esque expose of trial, tribulation and triumph. But even for a naturally gifted bull-shit artist like myself, there was always one question that I absolutely hated answering, one which required me to quite simply fabricate incredibly ridiculous stories that would induce vomit as I typed them. This question usually was structured as:

<strong>"Tell us about a time in your professional and/or personal life where you experienced adversity and what did you do to over come it?"</strong>

Call me jaded, but I think the only people who can, and should, write essays about adversity are those who actually have had adversity in their life:

- they have some sort of physical disability

- grew up in North Korea

- are part Native American

- are tone-deaf

- possess a small penis,

- etc...

But for the rest of us who grew up in relatively normal middle-class homes, in relatively normal North America (sans Mexico of course), the idea that we actually had any sort of challenge in our life that could merit a 1000 word essay is ridiculous. Now you take this regular pool of people, and you narrow it down to those who actually get into a top business school, and you are probably looking at the most privileged group of 20-somethings anywhere in the world.

So there I would sit in front of my computer, for hours at a time writing, backspacing, writing again and quite often simply deleting the whole thing. Going over ever minutae of my life, trying to find some adversity I could translate into a literary master piece of emotion and theatre. But anytime I would start writing, I couldn't stand the thought that this turgid mess would be read alongside some kid from Rwanda outlining how he escaped a Hutu death march. There is adversity, and then there is adversity.

<strong>When in doubt, play that race card.</strong>

Now you might say to yourself, "wait a second, you are brown, you got the racism angle, play that shit fool..."...Damn straight I did. Now, it would have been much easier if I was born in Selma, Alabama instead of  Brantford...Ontario...Canada. Brantford is exactly as white of a city as the name implies and I was one of maybe a handful of minorities in any of my classes.

I still remember my parents preparing me for the insults they expected I would receive on my first day of Grade 1.  But most surprisingly, (and even more telling of the tolerant nature of Canadian society),  from Grade 1- 12 it never happened. I can't remember one instance of racism in my youth.

<strong>Well...</strong>

I should say 'unprovoked' racism, because thats an important distinction. My dad is a true believer in the whole "teach a man to fish and feed him for life" thing. So in preparing me to be a victim, he taught me how to be the ultimate racist. Much to the shock of my teachers, classmates and other well-meaning members of society, I became known as that brown kid in an a white school who called anyone and everyone a 'white trash honkey' at the drop of a dime.

So yes, there were instances were somebody would call me a 'paki' or a 'sand ni$$er', but usually it was in response to me asking which brand of beer their mother planned on spending her welfare cheque on.

But I digress. In the end, the race card is exactly what I wrote about. Who knows what hair brained scenario I cooked up, but I wouldn't be surprised if it involved a burning cross, a camcorder, and a bunch of LAPD cops taking turns shoving nightsticks up my ass.

<strong>Nathan Muir said it best: 'Its all a game' .</strong>

Just like the GMAT, applying to business school is a game. If admissions officers are so dead-set on making applicants trod through the morass of shameless exposition that is passed off as the application essay, then every applicant should give them exactly what they want to hear. You can stand on your morality and choose not to, or you can play the game.

In the end, I take quiet comfort knowing that its the admissions officers that suffer in the short term. I can only imagine the level of cynicism that must come from reading thousands of essays on overcoming adversity submitted by kids that have ivy league backgrounds, and Fortune 500 credentials.

<strong>Its not the means sons, it’s the ends.</strong>

<img style="margin: 0px 5px;" src="http://360admissions.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Business-School.jpg" alt="" width="245" height="346" />

Look at this champ. Don't we all want to be like him? Sitting on a bench, wearing a suit, pimping  bitches, reading a pamphlet of some sort, with a stick up our ass and an MBA up our sleeve?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>31</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-07-06 13:47:33</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-07-06 13:47:33</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-beauty-of-the-business-school-application-process</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
		<title>social-capital2[1]</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 Jul 2011 05:51:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>varun.krishna</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/social-capital21.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>68</wp:post_id>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<title>pilates-enhance-work-life-balance[1]</title>
		<link></link>

	<item>
		<title>no-time-480[1]</title>
		<link></link>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>On puberty, photography and the stock market</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jul 2011 16:46:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=38</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Life seems to be one new life-altering phase coming after another. As kids, we all had our own little obsessions: some flipped pogs, others dressed up as Ninja Turtles, or some, as in my case, wrote down the name and registration of every airplane landing at Toronto's international airport (that's a whole other post on its own).

But we grow up and out of those things, and we soon find ourselves in the awkwardness and involuntary erections that mark puberty. Yet this too is just a phase, one in a long line of which defines our experience growing up.

It doesn't stop when we get older, the phases  just become more expensive and equally pretentious.

<strong>there is Digital Rebel inside each of us</strong>

Take for instance the inevitable  photography phase. This one is a real mid-late 20s phenomenon,  where we purchase a $$$ digital SLR  and then proceed to annoy every person we ever have dinner with again. You know what it is, its the jackass at a table of 12 that insists on making an entire round to take a picture of everyone's dish.

<img src="http://25.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_lausqcyim21qcfwoio1_400.jpg" alt="" />

Kim Jong Il staring the shit out of corn.

But tucked somewhere in between our Kodak (or should I say Hipstamatic) dreams, and our future spent raising Alpacas, comes the phase where we are seduced by Louis Rukeyser's wonderful world of the stock market.

At least with photography, there comes a point where every would-be Capa realizes that nobody wants to see a 100 picture gallery on Facebook devoted to a recent dinner at Chilis'. With investing, we only realize we suck when our bank account hits 0, and we're trading hand jobs for stock tips in a McDonald's parking lot (that didn't happen to me, i swear...).

<strong>Balloons and Oversized Cheques</strong>

<img src="http://www.hollywoodtoday.net/wp-content/uploads/2008/06/041028_mcmahon_vmed_930awidec.jpg" alt="" />

The allure of the stock market is hardly subtle. If you've just invested $100k in an English literature degree, the stock market feels like those letters you get from the Publisher's Clearinghouse Sweepstakes. You may have already won! Yet, instead of Ed McMahon standing at your doorstep with red balloons and an over sized cheque, its Jim Cramer, sleeves rolled up to this chin, welcoming you to a 'house of pleasure' (which interestingly enough I have discovered to be located on Sukhimvit Soi 11)

<strong>The stock market is the sickle-cell anemia of software engineers</strong>

The stock market is like a mid-autumn bug, a single sneeze turns into a torrent of phlegm in mere minutes. For software engineers (especially those of Indian heritage, like myself) we are particularly vulnerable to its spread. I am sure it comes as no surprise that there aren't many of us spending our Saturdays  captaining a softball team, running to cure AIDS,  or trolling through a farmer's market looking for that one special candle. We have far too much free time, that when combined with lofty salaries and the lack of any real hobby not involving a keyboard or Gandalf, makes us easy prey to the webmasters of <a href="http://www.SeekingAlpha.com">http://www.SeekingAlpha.com</a>.

So i did what i am sure many of us did, i snorted my first line of the drug known as the Wall Street Journal, and then enjoyed my first, among many, Erin Burnett and Maria Bartiromo lesbian fantasies.  I definitely was not alone. If you took a walk down the hallway of any Microsoft engineering building, I bet you will find as many aspiring hedge fund managers as you would Magic-playing virgins.

<strong>It's all about opportunity costs</strong>

Yet for me, I realized only after 4 years  ( and in business school ironically enough), that investing in the market as a small-time player like me is not worth it.  Even if by some miracle I eek out a 10% return above the S&amp;P 500, did that additional $X justify the amount of time I had to spend reading about Soybeans and listening to Charlie Gasparino?

<img src="http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/files/original/GasparinoCavuto_11-13.jpg" alt="" />

(sidebar: I'll say it, because we're all thinking it.  Charlie Gasparino is a tool box. not just a tool, he is like a god damned Craftsman series 100-piece socket wrench kit)

<strong>The market moves like Sauron's host...</strong>

The market is bigger than all of us. Its movement is like that of a breaking wave, nobody knows where its going to go, yet we all jump our surfboards and try to conquer it. And even more so, we all love to claim that we have.

But we don't. For every big win a small-time investor has in a stock, I am sure you could find an equally offsetting loss. I scored huge on betting on Northwest Airlines being bought out, but my enlightened decision to double down on GM debt in July of 2008 more than took care of that win. For every wall-street fund manager who is bullish on gold, I am sure you can find the same number who are bearish.

The scary truth is that we are all out here running around rubbing two sticks together trying to catch a flame.

<strong>As Costanza then added "and you're walking around here with a Zippo?!"</strong>

Now I won't say nobody wins in the markets. . Given enough capital, and insider knowledge, all of us can be playing the air guitar on a yacht like my boy Raj Rajaratnam:

<img src="http://cache.dealbreaker.com/uploads/2011/03/raj-rajaratnam-air-guitar3.jpg" alt="" />

I admit, this guy looks like a bit like El Douche. But the feds taking him out to the back of the woodshed over insider trading reminds me of when Comcast shut down my internet for downloading pirated music. Its not like I am the only person doing it.

In a world when every piece of public knowledge is already priced into a company's stock price, having knowledge that nobody else has is one sure fire to make money.

If you think that Raj needs to go to jail for breaking the sacrosanct rule of 'thou shall not trade on insider knowledge', than I bet you also believe that the securitization machine behind real estate's collapse was really designed to empower minority homeownership.

<strong>Enter the Rainman</strong>

Yet beyond those who have the insider knowledge and endless capital lie those  who simply have a gift. Just like Craig David once said, there are always those who were born to do it. Be it stacking cups, lifting plates, or pricing stocks, genius is everywhere. Look at this dog:
<div id="scid:5737277B-5D6D-4f48-ABFC-DD9C333F4C5D:37c68527-04a3-4f71-8961-b83a1d885da6" class="wlWriterEditableSmartContent" style="margin: 0px; display: inline; float: none; padding: 0px;">
<div><object width="448" height="252"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/RTTfmoklBok?hl=en&amp;hd=1" /><embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="448" height="252" src="http://www.youtube.com/v/RTTfmoklBok?hl=en&amp;hd=1"></embed></object></div>
</div>
&nbsp;

This dog be blowing bubbles, doing handstands and all sorts of other shit that I am sure gets all the neighborhood bitches in heat. Yet you wouldn't expect your retard dog to one day wake up and know how to skip double dutch? So it puzzles me when people run out to buy books with titles like "
<h3><img src="http://i1.calameoassets.com/110327181814-2c3bb154f0b0e34fa750cade9ce427a4/thumb.jpg" alt="" /></h3>
It's not as if Buffet was sitting around in Omaha 1940 shooting marbles and thinking to himself "hmmm, i really think i will only invest in stocks that have high cash-flow multiples and bullet-proof franchises". Even if by some miracle Buffet could write down every mental checkpoint he goes through when evaluating a stock, it still would be of no use to anybody but him. What he can't write down are those intangible instincts that he himself has learned to trust.

Books that claim to make you a master of the market are doing the exact same thing as the pills that promise to increase your penile girth. I'm surprised Amazon.com hasn't bundled them together as a super-saver deal.

<strong>When in doubt, blame the media. </strong>

I think what really turned me off the market are the same things which initially hooked me, the business media. The Wall Street Journal and CNBC are grocery market tabloids draped in sheep’s skin. They take random, otherwise unimportant pieces of data, find some idiot on the street who will make a case on it, and put it up in big bold letters to dress it up as the most important news since the Berlin Wall fell.

<strong>The US jobs report really depressed me</strong>

I really hate it when I hear that the US Labor Department's Non-Farm Payroll jobs report comes in below expectations. Not because I have some sympathy for that nameless Joe standing in an unemployment line, but rather I dread the 12-hour marathon coverage on CNBC that features Melissa Lee asking everyone, including the unpaid intern in the back of the studio, "does this news mean the end to our economic recovery?".

Or how about every time CNBC decides to aire the release of some bullshit metric pulled from the Vermont Department of Agriculture that is claimed to be the true predictor of our economic future?

But my favourite has to be the stock imagery the Wall Street Journal likes to throw around to really drive home the despair that comes with a 100-point down Dow day:

<img src="http://wa3.images.onesite.com/blogs.telegraph.co.uk/user/ambrose_evans-pritchard/trader.jpg?v=80000" alt="" />

<img src="http://gdb.rferl.org/C8EDD8A5-77D3-475D-A685-38B66929A513_mw800_s.jpg" alt="" width="397" height="298" />

<img src="http://blog.mlive.com/business_impact/2008/10/medium_100508-dow-wall-street-4.jpg" alt="" />

I bet the guy in the last photo is just really upset from not getting his 2pm sugar fix.

<strong>Please kid, call me when the market loses 700 points in one day</strong>

Maybe prior to September 2008 these types of stories kept me interested, but not anymore. Sons, I watched the Dow go from 14,000 down to 6,600, taking along with it most of my bschool tuition. If Lehman taught me one thing, its that short of a comet hitting the Federal Reserve building, nothing that CNBC or the WSJ claims to be a market-shaking headline can really be that bad or good in the long run.

The world goes on. The market adapts. I have accepted the market to be a shark-infested ocean that isn't worth all the effort.

<strong>And here's the rest of the story...</strong>

If I have one stock tip for any future would-be stock maven it would simply <strong>SPY</strong>

If you want a little bit more adventure for a minimum amount of work: diversify your money across maybe 3 major economic sectors, throw in maybe a bond ETF,  and avoid individual company purchases. Then have your wife/gf/bf, or in some people's case, a highly-intelligent dog,  change the password to your online brokerage account and not tell you.

After that, grab the SLR off the shelf, and go out and take some mother f*ckin pictures.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>38</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-07-13 16:46:10</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-07-13 16:46:10</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>on-puberty-photography-and-stocks</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="warren-buffet"><![CDATA[Warren Buffet]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[investing, stock market, warren buffet, ganfalf, sauron, lessons in life, photography, puberty]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_title</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[On puberty, photography and the stock market]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Like puberty, and photography, it seems all of us go through a stock picking phase of our life. the result of which is usually results in an abundance of tears and a reduction in liquidity.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The world needs a better app</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 Jul 2011 04:58:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>varun.krishna</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=47</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><strong>This town deserves a better class of criminal. And I'm going to give it to them.</strong></em>

<em><strong>Heath Ledger playing the Joker from the Dark Knight</strong></em>

It's amazing to me the transformative effect that smartphones and apps have on the basic way in which people in society function.

Observing this transformation is actually pretty simple when you get down to it.  On a given day, take a look at people around you and see if you can't convince yourself that at least half of them are flowing through the course of their day starting at that little screen, fully absorbed in a game, facebook, text message, or app.
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/cell-phones-sterile-31.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-53 aligncenter" title="cell-phones-sterile-3[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/cell-phones-sterile-31-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a></p>
Whether this change overall is one that has benefitted or destroyed the way society functions is a matter of opinion, but one thing is for certain - opportunity, certainly lies in exploiting the basic needs that have created a cell phone-obsessed society.

The phone has become a way to cultivate the root nature of people. In this post, I'm going to try to explain the root nature of all people as I see it, and how it matters to the companion devices we can't seem to live without.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/alone1.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-59 aligncenter" title="alone[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/alone1-300x236.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="236" /></a></strong></p>
<strong>Fear </strong>- Human beings are fear-driven creatures.  If we examine our true motivation for doing anything, we will usually find that at the very core, we do it because we fear something.  Whether it's going to church because you don't want to go to hell, or setting up a trust fund for your kid because you don't want his life to go to hell - it's really all the same thing.  Examine your true motivation for doing anything, and you will find that a fear is atached to it somewhere.  If I had to take a stab at it, I'd say that most human beings fear the thought of being alone.  And the phone? It's a way for you to know that you are in fact not alone. It's a way for you to feel that you are loved and a part of something bigger than you are.

<strong><a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/shapeimage_31.png"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-60" title="shapeimage_3[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/shapeimage_31-300x171.png" alt="" width="300" height="171" /></a></strong>

<strong>Escape </strong>- Human beings suffer from a constant "grass is greener" syndrome when it comes to being "in the moment".  No matter how happy you are, no matter what you are doing, the phone is a way for you to escape your current reality.  It's too difficult to sit in a subway train and just experience the feeling of being in a subway, it's unbearable to walk to the bar without reaching into your pocket, popping out your phone and texting someone.  The phone is a way for you to escape the present moment to whatever reality you choose to experience on the phone.

<a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/narcissist11.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-64" title="narcissist[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/narcissist11-230x300.jpg" alt="" width="230" height="300" /></a>

<strong>Narcisissm </strong>- People love themselves, and rightly so.  The phone is an expression mechanism for appreciation. To let people know that you have a life, to let them appreciate you and make you feel like that life matters.  With the concept of the status message and the wall I would give it to Facebook for inventing it.  For taking the concept of just the update/follow mechanism and focusing on that, I would give it to Twitter for perfecting it.  Finally, for giving it to you at your fingertips whenever you want it, I'd hand it to the phone for making it accessible wherever you are.

<a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/social-capital211.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-69" title="social-capital2[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/social-capital211.jpg" alt="" width="271" height="285" /></a>

<strong>Voyeurism </strong>- You probably know where I'm going with this. In the same way that they love themselves, people love to bask in others' misery/joy/pain. It's part of the whole feeling connected and not alone part, except for one important distinction.  We are all pervs.  Who doesn't enjoy seeing that so-and-so is in a domestic partnership with so-and-so.  It's interesting; it helps us compare our lives to others; hell, it calls for interesting table talk. And.....of course (you know where I'm going with this) - the phone is the best place to have that experience.

As you can probably tell, from the way I describe them, I think that these traits aren't exactly representitative of what most people would consider endearing qualities of humanity.  But the truth is, we're all a little depraved.  Every single one of us.  The phone is now the device that we as a population interact with more than the very people around us that we care so much about. The reasons are stated above.  It's all about the phone and it's all about the app.  Build the app along these constructs and you can't fail because you're applying it to a root cause of human ego.  And the phone, by virtue of it being a virtual companion to the human population - well built, well thought through, and well delivered,  has the potential to rope in all of us the same way facebook, twitter, and the rest of them did.

So what kind of app is this? Well, I don't quite know yet, but I am throwing the idea in some sort of direction for the time being.

First of all.  What does it need to be for people.  I think, at the end of the day, people want three things.  Love, approval, and appreciation. Let's call it <strong>Laa </strong>because it sounds good.  The phone is what gives us <strong>Laa</strong>. The app that ultimately delivers <strong>Laa</strong> is the app that will reign above all.

People would benefit from an app that connects their present reality to the reality they choose to escape from. An app that bridges the two gaps and helps them find satisfaction in the present moment.  An app that also preserves that satisfaction, while retaining the need for <strong>Laa </strong>that all fear-driven creatures possess.  An app that gives them the same basic qualities that all people crave - that satisfies their need for security (fear), interest (escape), self (narcisissm), and connection (voyeurism).

<strong>The world deserves a better class of app. </strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>47</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-07-19 04:58:08</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-07-19 04:58:08</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-world-needs-a-better-app</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="ego"><![CDATA[Ego]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="mobile"><![CDATA[mobile]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="people"><![CDATA[People]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="social"><![CDATA[Social]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[iPhone, Apps Human Nature, Ego, Fear, Love, Social, Transformation, Enlightenment, Narcicissm, Voyeurism, Social Media, Facebook, Twitter, Philosophy, Android, Google]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_title</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[iPhone App Design Principles Human Interaction]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[This posts describes a psychological profiling of human beings and their interactions with phones as a necessity in their day to day lives.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How the Space Shuttle saved the world&#8230;</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Jul 2011 19:50:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=73</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In between news flashes of Rupert Murdoch receiving the parliamentary equivalent of a rectal <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prolapse">prolapse</a>, and Obama attempting to do the same to Eric Cantor, one piece of news which seemed to get lost was the retirement of the U.S. Space Shuttle fleet.</p>  <p>As the Shuttle glides into the sunset,&#160; let me tell you a story you might have not heard before. We all know the U.S. Shuttle is just another $100 billion we now owe to the Chinese, but did you know that without it, we could all be standing in 3-day lineups for a pound of butter?</p>  <p><font size="4"><strong>Our story begins in 1971...</strong></font></p>  <p>When NASA previewed the design of the U.S. Space Shuttle it sent ripples of excitement throughout the world. However, in Moscow, deep within the Soviet Union's Kremlin, fear and worry plagued the Soviet Politburo.</p>  <p>When the Soviets saw the U.S. spending billions of dollars developing the Space Shuttle, it just didn't add up for them. Why would the U.S. pour those kind of resources into building an orbiter that clearly was neither cheaper nor more reliable than the existing generation of disposable boosters?</p>  <p>A just question, one that a lot of people in the U.S. government were also asking and one that NASA has yet to answer.</p>  <p>The Soviets, bless their paranoid little hearts, surmised that the Shuttle must be some sort of a secret defense department project to warrant such investment.&#160; In fact, Politburo officials feared that the U.S. had built into the Shuttle the secret capability to dive into the Earth's atmosphere, and <a href="http://worms.wikia.com/wiki/Super_Bunker_Buster">open up a can of nuclear whoop ass on Moscow</a>.</p>  <p>I don't even know where to begin with this, but lets try physics for a start! The U.S. Shuttle is a glider, it's not dive-bombing shit.&#160; Unless of course it was to be piloted by leftover <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamikaze">Japanese Kamikazes</a>.</p>  <p>Even if the U.S. Shuttle had a 747 strapped to its back, the next questions I would ask Brezhnev (or whatever <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_leaders_of_the_Soviet_Union">whack job</a> was running the Soviet Union at the time):</p>  <p><em>&quot;Dive bombing from space...really? is an ICBM too easy to launch?&quot;</em></p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://jspivey.wikispaces.com/file/view/2007.08.17icbm.JPG/34489797/2007.08.17icbm.JPG" /></p>  <p>The Soviets believed so deeply that the Shuttle was meant to be a surprise nuclear bomber that they said 'fuck it! lets build out own!'...</p>  <p><strong>Meet &quot;Buran&quot; (yes that's really what they named it). The Soviet Space Shuttle.</strong> <strong></strong></p>  <p>While the Chinese were (still) <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989#Military_action">running people over with tanks</a>, the Soviets had already mastered the art&#160; of counterfeiting U.S. intellectual property. Meet the crowning achievement of the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Chief_Directorate">KGB's 1st operational directorate</a>: the Soviet Space shuttle: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buran_(spacecraft)">&quot;Buran&quot;:</a></p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/32/Buran.jpg" /></p>  <p>Come on, just look at it. It's <strong>exactly</strong> the same as the U.S Shuttle...right down to the C.C.C.P sticker written on the left wing where you'd normally find U.S.A. . Even the same damn font.</p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://www.buran.ru/images/gif/mtkkman.gif" /></p>  <p>Good work Yuri, that’s some real original shit you designed there.</p>  <p>Buran actually did fly...once. In 1988, a full 8 years after the U.S. shuttle flew (more than enough time for Soviet engineers to watch enough of the NASA channel to reverse engineer the thing), Buran successfully completed its first flight. To give credit to the Soviets, it did complete its entire mission, including a landing, completely unmanned (something a U.S. shuttle never did)</p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://lide.uhk.cz/fim/student/vokraji2/obrazky/buran_landing.jpg" width="520" height="369" /></p>  <p>However, much like the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Romanov#Murder_of_Tsar_.26_Family">Romanovs</a>, this Russian story also has a sad ending. Buran's fate was sealed in 2002, when the only completed <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buran_program#Buran_hangar_collapse">Buran orbiter was destroyed when the hangar it was parked in roof collapsed</a>!</p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://files.abovetopsecret.com/images/member/d1e901ea00d2.jpg" width="528" height="396" /></p>  <p>Kudos to the Russians though, the choice to invest in building a manned Shuttle that could land all by itself was clearly the more effective use of time and resources than building a hangar that wouldn’t collapse during a downpour.</p>  <p>However, Buran did manage to achieve one thing: it nailed the coffin of the Soviet economy completely shut. At its peak during the 1980s, the Soviets had 150,000 people devoted to building Buran to close the “space bomber” race with the US.</p>  <p><strong>We really should thank &quot;Buran&quot;, we could all be eating borscht right now</strong></p>  <p>While many people, including myself, believe that Ronald Reagan was a bit of a clown for pouring billions of dollars into a variety of looney-tuned projects (<a href="http://www.nasaimages.org/luna/servlet/detail/nasaNAS~5~5~21057~125979:Freedom-Space-Station-Concept">Space Station Freedom</a>? <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_Defense_Initiative">Star Wars</a>?). What we didn't count on was the Soviet leadership reaching Sarah Palin-esque levels of ignorance.&#160; So Ron, wherever you are, I am sorry for calling you an idiot.</p>  <p><strong>So there you have it...</strong></p>  <p>The U.S. Space Shuttle, at $2 billion per launch, and with a fatality rate that rivals Somali Airlines, is a white elephant in every sense of the word. Sure, <a href="http://hubblesite.org/the_telescope/team_hubble/servicing_missions.php">servicing the Hubble telescope</a> was a real knee-slapping good time, and who can forget <a href="http://www2.wspa.com/blogs/tom-crabtree/2011/jul/08/experience-witnessing-john-glenns-shuttle-flight-ar-2086943/">John Glenn dragging his old ass all over the payload bay</a>?</p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://www.sti.nasa.gov/tto/Spinoff2008/images/hm_21.jpeg" width="529" height="346" /></p>  <p>But in truth, the U.S. Space Shuttle is <a href="http://worms.wikia.com/wiki/Buffalo_of_Lies">the buffalo of all lies</a>.</p>  <p>But it wasn't all for naught. The Cold War eventually ended, and the world was saved from nuclear holocaust, partly because the U.S. could afford to build more <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_elephant">white elephants</a> than the Russians could. So to the Enterprise, Columbia, Challenge, Endeavor, Atlantis, Discovery, and all those who designed, built, serviced and flew on them, I say thanks for helping to put those commie pricks in their place.</p>  <p>Mazel tov!</p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://rarelyknown.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/lenin_ipod.jpg" /></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The U.S. Space Shuttle program did as much to bring down the Soviet Union as did Ronald Reagan, McDonald's and Polish solidarity.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Why do we continue to pay attention to Moody&#039;s, Fitch and S&amp;P bond ratings?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Aug 2011 06:37:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=89</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[i&#039;d pay attention to financial advice given by a 17th century tulip vendor before listening to S&amp;P, Moody&#039;s or Fitch.<br /><br /><span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://www.quora.com/Why-do-we-continue-to-pay-attention-to-Moodys-Fitch-and-S-P-bond-ratings">Why do we continue to pay attention to Moody&#039;s, Fitch and S&amp;P bond ratings?</a></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>89</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-01 06:37:02</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-01 06:37:02</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>why-do-we-continue-to-pay-attention-to-moodys-fitch-and-sp-bond-ratings</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Dear Standard &amp; Poor&#8217;s, will the beatings never end?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Aug 2011 15:03:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=90</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>“There's an old saying in Tennessee - I know it's in Texas, probably in Tennessee - that says, fool me once, shame on - shame on you.  Fool me - you can't get fooled again.” </em>

- George W. Bush

Right now in some <a href="http://shop.crackerbarrel.com/">Cracker Barrel</a> deep within the suburban countryside of Dallas, George W Bush stews. That big pile of okra he was dreaming about all day, well that's going to go cold tonight. Laura knows he won't be able to attend to his beets, and she is sure tonight wont be the night he finally cracks the 4-peg barrier in the <a href="http://www.danobrien.ws/PegBoard.html">table top Peg Game</a>. And how could he? We all done got fooled again.

Well, Dubya isn't alone in his anger, I am fuming. Believe me when I say I gave a serious finger wagging to the <a href="http://www.standardandpoors.com/home/en/us">Standard &amp; Poor's web site</a> last night. And why shouldn't I?  S&amp;P pulled one straight out of O.J. Simpson's playbook: just 3 years after giving us a $1 trillion prolapse, S&amp;P has come right back and slapped us across the face with a large, <a href="http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Trout%20Slap">MIRC-eqsue trout</a>.

The craziest thing about S&amp;P cutting the U.S. government's debt rating isn't so much that they did it, but rather that anyone still cares to listen. This is the same S&amp;P, that along with Fitch, and Moody's attached AAA- credit ratings to anything up to and including the financial equivalent of <a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cdo2.asp">pieces of shit</a>. Well now, S&amp;P has stripped away this badge of fecal financial pride from us:

<img src="http://charities.newton.co.uk/core/library/images/sandp_aaa_rating_logo.jpg" alt="" />

Through trusted sources, I've learned that S&amp;P's mailroom actually ran out those AAA stickers, and there was a Tijuana municipal bond issue that needed one asap.

I wonder what S&amp;P's real beef with us is? You'd think that whomever was running the lemmings in that place would just tip-toe the fuck out of the country after 2008.  Its fun to slap bankers around over the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subprime_mortgage_crisis">'unfortunate credit incident'</a>, but you can't help feel a little sorry for them when the only 3 letters in a S&amp;P credit analyst's vocabulary were 'A', 'A', and 'A'.

<img src="http://calculable.files.wordpress.com/2011/02/kim_jong-il04.jpg?w=640&amp;h=438" alt="" width="443" height="303" />

“Fuck me, it’s soy sauce” – Kim Jong Il, 2002.

Out of that old chestnut known as the ‘global economic meltdown’, we caught <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angelo_Mozilo">Angelo Mozilo</a>, the SEC and Bernie Madoff all with their dicks buried firmly in the proverbial pie.  We celebrated when the media then led Goldman Sachs  out to the back of the wood shed for a not-so private whipping. But where's the bitch-slappage for S&amp;P, Moody's and Fitch?

These clowns were slapping on AAA-credit ratings so quickly you'd think it was 4pm at the local <a href="http://www.chiquita.com/">Chiquita</a> factory. As much as everybody took turns fucking the football when it came to valuing real estate debt, at least most of them can say it wasn't their job to know this stuff.

S&amp;P though? not so much.  I have to think there were at least a couple of really awkward moments in more than a few S&amp;P employee performance reviews that year. But I bet that pales in comparison to the nervous introductions at the 2009 annual ‘S&amp;P Does Habitat For Humanity' event .

And after all this,  with the absurdity of a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hulk_(film)">twice-rebooted comic franchise</a>, S&amp;P has come back and delivered a steel boot to our collective scrotum. What’s worse is that the SEC, Treasury and the rest of the financial world still listens to these <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_rating_agency">jokers</a>. I'd trust a bond-rating from S&amp;P like I would a plane ticket to Pakistan.

Something is not right with S&amp;P. <a href="http://www.mcgraw-hill.com/site/our-businesses/education">McGraw-Hill</a> owns them, and you wouldn't be the first to double-take hearing that. McGraw-Hill used to print my Grade 9 biology book, and I am pretty sure that textbooks are a McGraw-Hill core competency.  Maybe it's a 'Big Paper' conspiracy. Create enough chaos, and you'll sell more textbooks full of history.

We all know the U.S. is going broke. This news isn’t exactly <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_War_air_campaign">bombs over Baghdad</a>. I also don't think any bond traders are walking to their Bloombergs this morning thinking "wow that Medicare bit S&amp;P mentioned really took me by surprise!"

If there is any hope for us, let it rest in the market. This whole S&amp;P downgrade is as academic as it is ridiculous. The invisible hands that guide along the  bids and asks of the sovereign debt markets, well I hope they all laughed like I did when they heard the news. S&amp;P, Moody's or Fitch sharing their recommendations on credit should carry the same weight as pilates tips from Wilford Brimley.

<img src="http://s2.n4g.com/media/11/news/25000/27629_0.jpg" alt="" />

Which weapon will S&amp;P use on us next? Please not the <a href="http://worms2d.info/Super_Sheep_(Aqua_Sheep)">sheep</a>.

I do hope that whomever at S&amp;P carries this beef with America has finally slayed their blood lust. Never mind the threat from Al Qaeda or any of its branded subsidiaries, I don't think we can handle any more beat downs at the hands of the McGraw-Hill Group of Companies.

<img src="http://www0.gsb.columbia.edu/students/organizations/saba/conferences/2011/images/speakers/deven_sharma.jpg" alt="" />

Deven Sharma – President of S&amp;P. No doubt a beacon of pride in the Indian community. It’s a shame he’s running the equivalent of a 4pm strip club buffet.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

Files";s:12:"PSModulePath";s:45:"C:Windowssystem32WindowsPowerShellv1.0Modules";s:6:"PUBLIC";s:13:"C:UsersPublic";s:11:"SystemDrive";s:2:"C:";s:10:"SystemRoot";s:9:"C:Windows";s:4:"TEMP";s:13:"C:WindowsTEMP";s:3:"TMP";s:13:"C:WindowsTEMP";s:10:"USERDOMAIN";s:7:"WINHOST";s:8:"USERNAME";s:4:"W06$";s:11:"USERPROFILE";s:36:"C:Windowssystem32configsystemprofile";s:6:"windir";s:9:"C:Windows";s:9:"FCGI_ROLE";s:9:"RESPONDER";s:18:"HTTP_CACHE_CONTROL";s:9:"max-age=0";s:15:"HTTP_CONNECTION";s:10:"keep-alive";s:19:"HTTP_CONTENT_LENGTH";s:3:"323";s:17:"HTTP_CONTENT_TYPE";s:33:"application/x-www-form-urlencoded";s:11:"HTTP_ACCEPT";s:63:"text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8";s:19:"HTTP_ACCEPT_CHARSET";s:30:"ISO-8859-1,utf-8;q=0.7,*;q=0.3";s:20:"HTTP_ACCEPT_ENCODING";s:17:"gzip,deflate,sdch";s:20:"HTTP_ACCEPT_LANGUAGE";s:14:"en-US,en;q=0.8";s:11:"HTTP_COOKIE";s:0:"";s:9:"HTTP_HOST";s:14:"www.oscial.com";s:12:"HTTP_REFERER";s:128:"http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=90&utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=dear-standard-poors-when-will-the-beatings-stop";s:15:"HTTP_USER_AGENT";s:119:"Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8) AppleWebKit/534.30 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/12.0.742.112 Safari/534.30";s:11:"HTTP_ORIGIN";s:21:"http://www.oscial.com";s:20:"IIS_UrlRewriteModule";s:10:"7.1.0761.0";s:12:"APPL_MD_PATH";s:20:"/LM/W3SVC/25679/ROOT";s:18:"APPL_PHYSICAL_PATH";s:13:"E:weboscialco";s:9:"AUTH_TYPE";s:0:"";s:13:"AUTH_PASSWORD";s:0:"";s:9:"AUTH_USER";s:0:"";s:11:"CERT_COOKIE";s:0:"";s:10:"CERT_FLAGS";s:0:"";s:11:"CERT_ISSUER";s:0:"";s:17:"CERT_SERIALNUMBER";s:0:"";s:12:"CERT_SUBJECT";s:0:"";s:14:"CONTENT_LENGTH";s:3:"323";s:12:"CONTENT_TYPE";s:33:"application/x-www-form-urlencoded";s:13:"DOCUMENT_ROOT";s:13:"E:weboscialco";s:17:"GATEWAY_INTERFACE";s:7:"CGI/1.1";s:5:"HTTPS";s:3:"off";s:13:"HTTPS_KEYSIZE";s:0:"";s:19:"HTTPS_SECRETKEYSIZE";s:0:"";s:19:"HTTPS_SERVER_ISSUER";s:0:"";s:20:"HTTPS_SERVER_SUBJECT";s:0:"";s:11:"INSTANCE_ID";s:5:"25679";s:13:"INSTANCE_NAME";s:10:"OSCIAL.COM";s:18:"INSTANCE_META_PATH";s:15:"/LM/W3SVC/25679";s:10:"LOCAL_ADDR";s:11:"96.31.35.68";s:10:"LOGON_USER";s:0:"";s:15:"PATH_TRANSLATED";s:42:"E:weboscialcowordpresswp-comments-post.php";s:12:"QUERY_STRING";s:0:"";s:11:"REMOTE_ADDR";s:14:"68.166.128.106";s:11:"REMOTE_HOST";s:14:"68.166.128.106";s:11:"REMOTE_PORT";s:5:"15150";s:11:"REMOTE_USER";s:0:"";s:14:"REQUEST_METHOD";s:4:"POST";s:15:"SCRIPT_FILENAME";s:42:"E:weboscialcowordpresswp-comments-post.php";s:11:"SCRIPT_NAME";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:11:"SERVER_NAME";s:14:"www.oscial.com";s:11:"SERVER_PORT";s:2:"80";s:18:"SERVER_PORT_SECURE";s:1:"0";s:15:"SERVER_PROTOCOL";s:8:"HTTP/1.1";s:3:"URL";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:14:"ORIG_PATH_INFO";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:8:"PHP_SELF";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:12:"REQUEST_TIME";s:10:"1312821347";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Is it real or is it fake? in the end, it&#8217;s just street meat</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Aug 2011 18:10:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=98</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I love <a href="http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=street%20meat">street meat</a>. No matter how much of a bleeding-heart, granola-eating liberal I have become, if I am outside at 4am and <a href="http://www.cloverfieldmovie.com/">Cloverfield</a> isn't charging up and down 7th avenue, you can find me enjoying a nice plate of lamb on rice at the famous <a href="http://www.yelp.com/biz/53rd-and-6th-halal-cart-new-york">'Halal Guys'</a> street cart at 53rd street and 6th avenue.

Yet, no matter the night, or the company I keep, my street food adventure always begins with some jackass asserting that they will only go to the "real" cart, and not any one of the 2 other carts on the same block which claim to be apart of the same street food empire as the original.

Never mind that the "real" cart could have a line stretching 3/4 of the way to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seventh_Avenue_(Manhattan)">7th avenue</a>, and take 30 minutes to clear while the other 2 carts on the same block sit idle. I've gone to this block in a torrential downpour and even then, without fail, there was a lineup of 15 die-hards, all of whom were patiently waiting at the "real" cart while battling the onset of pneumonia.

I am convinced that we will see a peaceful settlement of the Israel-Palestine dispute before New Yorker's will ever agree on whether all 3 carts are truly the same 'Halal Guys' carts, or rather <a href="http://www.ibtimes.com/welcome.html?surl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ibtimes.com%2Farticles%2F198206%2F20110815%2Ffake-apple-store-china-chinese-22-smart-store-iphone-5-september-7.htm">1 Apple Store surrounded by 2 Chinese fakes</a>.

Of all the asinine debates I hear during the course of my day, the street meat debate is most frustrating. This is not <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, nor is it the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_of_Control">LOC</a> in Kashmir, this is pretty cut and dry: they are all the same!

But to clear the record, let us look at the situation with this amazing visual I created:

<a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/3a7e5d13cb31_8A16/FoodCart.jpg"><img style="background-image: none; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; display: inline; padding-top: 0px; border: 0px;" title="FoodCart" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/images/3a7e5d13cb31_8A16/FoodCart_thumb.jpg" alt="FoodCart" width="488" height="409" border="0" /></a>

If you are one of those who proclaim that there is only one true street cart, I just have a few questions that I’d like you to help me out with:

<strong><span style="font-size: small;">Why hasn't the original "Halal Guy" noticed?</span></strong>

Ok, so if there is only one real street food cart, that means that the 2 other carts are copying everything about the original one (save for the Arab dude with the 3 foot beard who works weekends). All the way down to the bags, forks and t-shirts that the crew wears, it all is the same!  And to boot, they are doing all of this just  20 meters away from the original!

If this were true, then let me posit this: wouldn't there be a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worms_(series)">Worms</a> like amount of tension along that block between the vendors?

Wouldn't the "original" street car have a big sign attached to it saying "hey, those 2 other carts are a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worms_(series)">buffali-of-lies</a>"?

Not to assume the ethnicity of the vendors, but it does cross my mind that people from those countries have thrown rocks for much less of a crime.

<strong><span style="font-size: small;">Forget the original "Halal Guy", wouldn't an investment banker notice?</span></strong>

Again if we assume that all 3 carts are independent, then we run into the next logical wall: microeconomics.  <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microeconomics">Microeconomic</a> theory teaches us that a freely-competitive environment with multiple supplies will cause all suppliers' economic profits to 0.

If they were all different, then wouldn't each cart begin to undercut the other or offer distinguishing advantages if they were each run by separate owners? Given the volume of people coming to the block just to buy street meat, a profit-maximizing owner would attempt to steal from the long line by offering cheaper prices, wider menu selections, or maybe just a hot girl showing some ass.

Even worse, how could any of the countless bankers which walk out of the UBS building not see the pitch-book possibilities that a 3-cart merge provides?

Think about it, imagine if they were all owned by the same company: you could completely standardize the meat and utensil supply chain. You could save money by having the same packaging, bags, utensils and sauces. You could build brand awareness by printing custom t-shirts for all workers to wear....oh wait, they do that <span style="text-decoration: underline;">all</span> of that already. damn!

<strong><span style="font-size: small;">Even the real Halal Guy says:  "yes, its the same!"</span></strong>

This could be the real smoking gun of this case. One night, after handing over my 6-bones to the long-beard at the "real" cart, I asked him, "so what's the deal with those 2 fake carts?". To which he responded, "not fake! they real!"  That sounds good enough for me.

<strong><span style="font-size: small;">But really, you are eating lamb/chicken-on-rice</span></strong>

At the end of the day, you are eating shaved lamb, laid across a giant wad of rice, with a cut up pita bread and about 3 blades of lettuce. This ain't exactly <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foie_gras">foie gras</a>, and the Arab dude aint <a href="http://www.yelp.com/biz/jean-georges-new-york">Jeans Georges</a>. Does it really matter if your shaved lamb comes from the fake cart or the real one? At 4am, with vodka dripping down your shirt, are you telling me that you are suddenly a Halal connoisseur?

<img src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-D-OCaaYcHms/TgKaPaIlSoI/AAAAAAAABMA/07BdPY1NcHI/s1600/kim+jong+il+gourmets.jpg" alt="" />

<span style="font-size: x-small;">“Fools, I wanted chicken on rice!” – Kim Jong Il</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: small;">The prosecution rests.</span></strong>

There you have it. Even <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcia_Clark">Marcia Clark</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Pelosi">Nancy Pelosi</a> working together couldn't screw this case up. The evidence on the ground all point towards all of these carts being the same. Yet, I know this falls on deaf ears. I see myself in the same position as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galileo_Galilei">Galileo</a>, or <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus">Copernicus</a>. In the annals of intellectual persecution, the existence of multiple "real" street meat carts will most certainly bring down the same scorn that the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geocentric_model">Earth not being the center of the universe</a> once did.

Only time will tell if my voice is heard, or if I am strung up by the NYC street meat <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inquisition">Inquisition</a>. In the end, it might just be that people enjoy queuing up, even if its for street-meat and its 4am.  In this case, I have to ask: what is the real attraction late-night at 53rd &amp; 6th: the meat or the line?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[You present some pretty convincing arguments. But, I don't think the debate of real vs. fake isn't limited to whether the others are simply copycats or not. You could argue that the other carts are merely a franchising of the original which to many is in fact just another copycat fake. I bet the lunch meats from the original Subway started out a lot different than the seven variations on turkey meat we that we enjoy in today's $5 footlong of the month.]]></wp:comment_content>

deflate";s:20:"HTTP_ACCEPT_LANGUAGE";s:5:"en-us";s:11:"HTTP_COOKIE";s:0:"";s:9:"HTTP_HOST";s:14:"www.oscial.com";s:12:"HTTP_REFERER";s:37:"http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=98";s:15:"HTTP_USER_AGENT";s:111:"Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8) AppleWebKit/534.50 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/5.1 Safari/534.50";s:11:"HTTP_ORIGIN";s:21:"http://www.oscial.com";s:20:"IIS_UrlRewriteModule";s:10:"7.1.0761.0";s:12:"APPL_MD_PATH";s:20:"/LM/W3SVC/25679/ROOT";s:18:"APPL_PHYSICAL_PATH";s:13:"E:weboscialco";s:9:"AUTH_TYPE";s:0:"";s:13:"AUTH_PASSWORD";s:0:"";s:9:"AUTH_USER";s:0:"";s:11:"CERT_COOKIE";s:0:"";s:10:"CERT_FLAGS";s:0:"";s:11:"CERT_ISSUER";s:0:"";s:17:"CERT_SERIALNUMBER";s:0:"";s:12:"CERT_SUBJECT";s:0:"";s:14:"CONTENT_LENGTH";s:3:"617";s:12:"CONTENT_TYPE";s:33:"application/x-www-form-urlencoded";s:13:"DOCUMENT_ROOT";s:13:"E:weboscialco";s:17:"GATEWAY_INTERFACE";s:7:"CGI/1.1";s:5:"HTTPS";s:3:"off";s:13:"HTTPS_KEYSIZE";s:0:"";s:19:"HTTPS_SECRETKEYSIZE";s:0:"";s:19:"HTTPS_SERVER_ISSUER";s:0:"";s:20:"HTTPS_SERVER_SUBJECT";s:0:"";s:11:"INSTANCE_ID";s:5:"25679";s:13:"INSTANCE_NAME";s:10:"OSCIAL.COM";s:18:"INSTANCE_META_PATH";s:15:"/LM/W3SVC/25679";s:10:"LOCAL_ADDR";s:11:"96.31.35.68";s:10:"LOGON_USER";s:0:"";s:15:"PATH_TRANSLATED";s:42:"E:weboscialcowordpresswp-comments-post.php";s:12:"QUERY_STRING";s:0:"";s:11:"REMOTE_ADDR";s:14:"71.231.138.153";s:11:"REMOTE_HOST";s:14:"71.231.138.153";s:11:"REMOTE_PORT";s:5:"64570";s:11:"REMOTE_USER";s:0:"";s:14:"REQUEST_METHOD";s:4:"POST";s:15:"SCRIPT_FILENAME";s:42:"E:weboscialcowordpresswp-comments-post.php";s:11:"SCRIPT_NAME";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:11:"SERVER_NAME";s:14:"www.oscial.com";s:11:"SERVER_PORT";s:2:"80";s:18:"SERVER_PORT_SECURE";s:1:"0";s:15:"SERVER_PROTOCOL";s:8:"HTTP/1.1";s:3:"URL";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:14:"ORIG_PATH_INFO";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:8:"PHP_SELF";s:31:"/wordpress/wp-comments-post.php";s:12:"REQUEST_TIME";s:10:"1313607098";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";s:15:"1313607824.2771";s:7:"message";s:44:"admin changed the comment status to approved";s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:5:"admin";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Happiness</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 20 Aug 2011 09:37:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>varun.krishna</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=105</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Human beings are blessed with consciousness and free will.  That distinguishes us from every living species on earth. To me that means we can think, act, judge and generally do what we want (within reason).

So why is shit so fucked in the world?  Why do wars, politics, religious conflicts, etc... happen over and over again.  To me it boils down to a very simple yet sad fact.  At the end of the day people choose not to be happy with their reality.

Try living your life in eternal gratitude for the fact that it's your life and not one thing you can do will ever change that.  Love your life.  Love yourself.  See yourself as someone who is happy.  Someone who can handle anything life throws at you with a smile and because after all it's your life.  It will continue along a path that's way bigger than the next curve you can't quite see around.  The universe has a plan for you that you can't imagine, so while you're on the journey why not enjoy it.  Don't over indulge in the ups, because there are always going to be downs.  If you're indifferent to the flow then by definition you'll never be unhappy.

Think of your life as perfect by definition and beautiful for everything it gives you.  Remember that the thrill of victory would never taste sweet were it not for the agony of defeat.

It's easy to live your life absorbed in the the twists and turns that life throws you way.  But why do that? Why not CHOOSE to be happy.  Live your life in eternal gratitude just because you have the privilege of experiencing life itself.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>105</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-20 09:37:07</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-20 09:37:07</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>happiness</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<title>an oxymoron wrapped in a hyperbole?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Aug 2011 19:06:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=147</guid>
