	<item>
		<title>i know that face...</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Aug 2011 02:46:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=163</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><p class="post-image "><img src="http://108.6.2.14/KlinkService/Images/1314585903-imageurl.jpg" width=600 height=448/></p><p>i know that face...</p></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>163</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-29 02:46:08</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-29 02:46:08</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>i-know-that-face</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="lifeintechnicolor"><![CDATA[#lifeintechnicolor]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Time.....really?</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Aug 2011 05:57:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>varun.krishna</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=169</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/pilates-enhance-work-life-balance1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-211" title="pilates-enhance-work-life-balance[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/pilates-enhance-work-life-balance1-300x300.jpg" alt="" width="281" height="256" /></a><strong>Time</strong> is an interesting thing. For many of us - it plays an important role in the functioning of our day to day existence.  An ideal day for your average person might be getting up at 6,  working out or taking care of kids till 8.  Then it's off to work; a solid 9-5 of strategic strategery over a series of 30 to 60 minute engagements.  Then maybe it's back home or some grocery shopping/sporting event followed by dinner and some TV, and in bed at 11, where the recommended 7 hours of sleep are applied.

This schedule with slight variances of planned activities repeats - 5 days a week.  On the weekend it might be Costco and....well...you get the idea.

Here's an interesting social experiment.  What would it be like if you <strong>didn't think about time at all</strong> in the functioning of your day to day life?

<a href="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/no-time-4801.gif"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-212" title="no-time-480[1]" src="http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/no-time-4801-300x300.gif" alt="" width="203" height="149" /></a>

Ok. wait - that's a bit extreme.

Let's say that you cared <em>less</em> about time.

Hmmm, maybe still too extreme.

All right.

Let's just say you got <strong>real good</strong> at recognizing when you were in situations where time simply doesn't matter. Would that make you more relaxed?  Could it improve your sense of peace and well-being?

Let's consider two different examples as illustration:

<strong><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 10px; border: 10px solid black;" src="http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2009/images/04/20/art.airline.crowded.passengers.jpg" alt="" width="292" height="219" /></strong><strong>#1 - Your plane just stopped at the gate - it's been a long flight. You're seated in row 33F and the captain just switched off the seatbelt sign.</strong>

The aircraft becomes a frenzy of people getting out of their seats, reaching for their bags, and making sure that they're prepared to deplane as soon as possible.  When you think about it - it is a virtual certainty that the speed at which you get off the plane - be it seated or standing is based on the fact that everyone in front of you deplanes first and in order.

It has nothing to do with whether you got up or not.  Yet - subconsciously - there is a need for us to "argue" with time here.  I'll wager that whether seated or standing - you will get off the plane in roughly the same amount of time.  I'll also wager that scrambling up out of your seat, for a shot at your bag, ensuring that you are standing and ready however - may add just a tiny bit of hassle to your state of mind.  The next time your plane docks - chill out and relax until it's time to get up - it won't take any longer.

<strong><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 10px; border: 10px solid black;" src="http://bigbaddie.com/wp-content/uploads/2007/08/traffic.jpg" alt="" width="376" height="280" />#2 - You're stuck in traffic.</strong>

This one's easy because we've all been there.  Changing lanes wildly because the right lane for some reason seems to be edging along slightly faster.  Frustration.  Anger.  Annoyance.  A feeling of helplessness even.  When you're stuck and there's only one route to get there - there's nothing you can do.  But there's also no point in spending a second worrying about it.  The stark reality of course is that traffic will move according to the rules of flow. (Much like everything in the universe but that's a different post) It's a function of the amount of space on the road, the speed limit, and the level of congestion, the time of day, incidents etc..

Moments of slight acceleration and deceleration, will (on average) do <strong>nothing</strong> to accelerate the time it will take us to reach our destination.  Shortcuts excluded, many of us repeatedly find ourselves in this situation.  In New York and LA for example it's simply a fact of life.  Sure it's irritating but buddy, there isn't a damn thing you can do about it!  You'll reach there according to the time that it takes you to get through the traffic to get there.  That time is known because it's going to happen.  It is a fact.  It is reality.  Don't argue with it - just accept it, appreciate it, and think beyond it.  Trust the universe.  If you were supposed to get there on time - you would have, but <strong>this time </strong>(pun intended) - you're supposed to get there late and maybe that in an of itself <strong>is the adventure</strong>.   Remember the saying that it's not the destination, it's the journey.  Next time: pick a lane.  Stay in it.  Relax.  Forget about the destination and enjoy the ride instead - maybe you'll see something interesting along the way. Who knows.

Another interesting example is when we're faced with decisions that are marginally better than each other but for all intensive purposes the same.  For example -
<ul>
	<li>which <a href="http://webpages.scu.edu/ftp/mburrill/images/airport-security-line.jpg">security line </a>at the airport to stand in</li>
	<li>two desirable entrees at a restaurant</li>
	<li>chicken and rice carts at <a href="http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xEnNFXtMLDF5kZDxfaCJgA?select=6NfT2GMOAAZBQEj3KtBmuw">53rd and 6th</a></li>
	<li>a <a href="http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Concrete%20Donkey">concrete donkey</a> or an <a href="http://worms.wikia.com/wiki/Armageddon_(Weapon)">armageddon</a></li>
</ul>
Things where it's not obviously clear which decision would <strong>save you more time or result in the "right action"</strong>.

Here's an interesting revelation - what if <strong>all decisions are correct</strong>.  The right decision is the one you make.  By definition it is perfect because, well, you made it and it's already in the process of happening.  It's reality.

Now here's the rub.  Don't make the decision at all.  Leave it to the universe to decide.

<strong>In any situation where there is a marginal difference between two outcomes, flip a coin and do what the coin dictates - not because of time - but becasue of the experience that is created by whatever decision is made for you.  Don't spend a second looking back on it, and just keep going.</strong>

At the end of it all, we let ourselves experience situations where we care about time more than is really necessary.  That "caring" is wasted energy expenditure that adds nothing but a reversal of value to our lives in the form of stress, irritation, and wasted cycles of negative thought.

Being less cognizant of time could make our lives happier and more fullfilling.  Try indifference for a change.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>169</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-30 05:57:57</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-30 05:57:57</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>time-really</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<title>This was a great idea</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Aug 2011 17:40:18 +0000</pubDate>

		<title>This was a great idea</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 27 Aug 2011 17:55:42 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>This was a great idea</title>

	<item>
		<title>irene&#039;s wrath</title>
		<link></link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Aug 2011 19:04:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>bobby.gill</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.oscial.com/wordpress/?p=146</guid>
		<description></description>

		<wp:post_name>test-2</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="lifeintechnicolor"><![CDATA[#lifeintechnicolor]]></category>
